Headline.Para: Colleges Make It Easier for Older Students; Initiatives include revising schedules and financial-aid packages

LeadPara.Para: To woo adult students, many colleges and technical schools are reducing the time and money it takes to earn a degree or certification.

Often in tandem with state governments concerned about a lack of qualified applicants for jobs that require advanced learning, schools on this path—typically community and regional colleges and vocational schools—are rethinking credit hours and semester-based schedules. Some states, meanwhile, are revising the financial-aid packages they offer.

TailParas.Para: The shift recognizes an unfortunate paradox: Some 41% of students enrolled in higher education are 25 or older, according to the National Center for Education Statistics, but colleges often don't meet older students' needs. Adults frequently struggle to balance work and family responsibilities with studies. About 38% of students with outside financial, work or family obligations leave in the first year, says the Lumina Foundation, a nonprofit that works to make higher education more available.

"It shouldn't be this hard," says Sarah Ancel, a senior vice president for Complete College America, a nonprofit that advocates for higher graduation rates. But higher education in the U.S. wasn't built for adult students or the complexity of their lives, Ms. Ancel says.

Many older students don't know they are eligible for federal financial aid and fail to fill out the Free Application for Federal Student Aid. Meanwhile, many state-aid programs favor younger students by requiring full-time enrollment, says Sarah Pingel, a senior policy analyst at the Education Commission of the States, a nonpartisan nonprofit that focuses on education policy.
State grants

But some states are removing these barriers by offering, and actively marketing, scholarships that pay the remaining balance owed by adult students after federal aid has been applied, and by rethinking requirements for state funded financial aid as well.

In Indiana, the Workforce Ready Grant pays tuition and fees for adults who want to earn a postsecondary certificate in such industries as construction, health and life sciences, information tech, logistics and manufacturing. Students can be full or part time but must apply first for federal aid. Employer Training Grants help companies pay for postsecondary certificates for their employees, too, says Teresa Lubbers, Indiana's commissioner for higher education. And finally, there are Adult Student Grants, which award as much as $2,000 a year to older students pursuing associate's or bachelor's degrees or certificates in another field.

The Tennessee Reconnect scholarship pays tuition and fees for students earning an associate's degree or postsecondary certification, full or part time, at any of the state's 13 community colleges and 27 colleges of applied technology. Previously, this scholarship could only be used for the colleges of applied technology. Applicants, again, must apply for federal aid first.

Some schools are trying to help adult students earn degrees or certificates faster, in some cases by putting more effort into prior-learning assessments in which students who prove they already have some required skills, learned, say, in the military, receive credit toward graduation.

Similar assessments have at times been offered on an ad hoc basis in the past. By contrast, Tennessee Higher Education Commission & Student Assistance Corp. now has created statewide standards for prior-learning assessments and has promoted the program, TimewiseTN, as part of recruitment and enrollment.

At University of Louisville in Kentucky, students in an introductory class can earn as many as 42 credits toward a 120-credit degree if they demonstrate proficiency in certain knowledge and skills, according to Matt Bergman, a program director and assistant professor at the school's College of Education and Human Development.

Anthony Carnevale, a research professor and director of the Georgetown University Center on Education and the Workforce, says students should ask schools about employment and wage information for graduates of specific programs since testing competency can be subjective, especially if there are no professional certifications or statewide standards. Some states, such as Minnesota, North Carolina, Florida and Colorado, have put this information online, but if the data is difficult to find, Dr. Carnevale suggests speaking with alumni directly. "There needs to be more transparency," he says.
Accelerated learning

In addition to standardizing and promoting prior-learning assessments, some schools are offering compressed courses, sometimes lasting only four weeks rather than the usual 18. Accelerated courses like this can be taken year round online, in person or as a hybrid. Either way, a big advantage is that it allows students to carry the equivalent of a full-time course load on a part-time schedule and graduate with a baccalaureate in four years, says Ms. Ancel, explaining that the ability to focus on one course at a time makes it easier for older students to manage their schedules, including their job and family responsibilities.

At Bellevue University, a private, nonprofit university in Bellevue, Neb., about 63% of its undergraduate students are enrolled in accelerated programs. A white paper issued by Complete College America highlights that the four-year graduation rate for students enrolled in accelerated courses for a baccalaureate in business at Bellevue was more than 70%, compared with 24% for students enrolled in traditional classes. The paper showed students enrolled in accelerated programs around the U.S. also had better completion rates, GPAs and test scores. The paper acknowledges that motivated students may self-select into these programs.

In another adult-friendly education model, referred to as open-entry or early-exit, students demonstrate proficiency in a subject area or mastery of specific skill through projects, papers, exams, presentations or another type of formal assessment and then go onto the next requirement—always moving at their own pace, which is usually faster than the old system.

Similarly, in the University of Wisconsin's Flexible Option program, "there are no courses, credit hours or semesters," says Aaron Brower, provost and vice chancellor University of Wisconsin-Extension. Rather than enroll in courses worth a certain number of credit hours, students pass assessments showing mastery of key skills or competencies.

For example, if students earning a degree in computer science already know how to build a website, they can demonstrate their mastery through an assessment without completing predetermined coursework and then move onto the next set of competencies.

But when a required skill is new to the student, the material is presented online, and an academic-success coach directs the student to additional books, articles, taped lectures or tutoring. Students work through the new material at their own pace and take an assessment when they are ready. The program offers associate degrees or bachelor's of science degrees in business, biomedical science and diagnostic imaging, information science and technology and nursing.

Mr. Brower says students can begin the program at the beginning of a month, rather than when a term begins. They pay $2,250 for three months and can usually save time and money if they move quickly. Students on average shave about six months off the time it takes to earn a BS. Students with associate degrees in nursing can usually complete bachelor's degrees in nursing in 18 months rather than two years. The school plans to expand program to out of state nursing students.

At the University of Wisconsin in Madison the model has also been applied to postgraduate certification in substance-abuse treatment. Previously, professionals would attend classes for about a year before they could take a national exam. Now the substance-use-disorders-counselor certification requirements take on average between three to six months because the professionals who enroll usually have some practical knowledge and can apply it to pass certain assessments quickly.

The school hopes to expand the substance-abuse program to students in other states, says Mary Thompson, assistant dean of academic affairs at the University of Wisconsin-Madison's division of continuing studies. Jobs for substance-abuse, behavioral-disorder and mental-health counselors are expected to grow 20% over the next decade, representing about 51,600 jobs, the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics says.
Ms. Ward is a writer in Mendham, N.J. Email:reports@wsj.com.
